description.narrative: Sida tog år 2012 (inom ramen för den särskilda satsningen för demokratisering och yttrandefrihet - UF2009/27888/UP) emot en ansökan från den brasilianska organisationen Conectas Direitos Humanos, för stöd till projektet ”Strengthening Human Rights Defenders Work and Democracy in the Global South” 2012-2013 (12 månader). Sida bedömde då att ansökan var relevant för Strategin för särskilda insatser för demokratisering och yttrandefrihet 2012-2014. Projektet genomfördes under 2013 med goda resultat. Conectas har skickat en förlängningsansökan som Sida har bedömt tillsammans med tidigre uppnåda resultat. Sida anser att det är relevant att fortsätta stödja Conectas under ytterligare en projektperiod av 12 månader med en budget av SEK 1,160,000. Conectas Direitos Humanos grundades 2001 i Sao Paulo Brasil av MR-grupper. Det övergripande syftet med projektet är att främja MR i Globala Syd, genom att förstärka MR-försvarare och deras organisationer genom kapacitetsutveckling, internationellt nätverkande syd-syd, och påverkansarbete inom de internationella forumen. Målgrupperna för projektet är framförallt MR-försvarare, MR-aktivister och deras organisationer. Sida bedömer att resultatramverket är logiskt och tillräckligt bra för uppföljning. Det saknas baslinjedata, men organisationen har använt rekommendationer från en extern projektutvärdering vid utvecklingen av den nya projektmålen. Indikatorerna är både kvantitativa och kvalitativa, vilket är en positiv utgångspunkt för att kunna göra projektuppföljning. Budgeten anses rimligt och realistisk i förhållande till planerade aktiviteter och förväntade resultat. Förutom Sida, bidrar också Open Society Foundations, Sigrid Rausing Trust, Fundacao Carlos Chagas, EU och ett antal privata givare från Brasilien med stöd till projektet. Sida bedömer att Conectas har bra system för styrning och administrativa rutiner. Organisationen har 12 års erfarenhet av liknande insatser.

The interventions outlined in this proposal aim at strengthening Human Rights Defenders' work and Democracy in the Global South namely in Latin America, Africa, and Asia, through education, research and advocacy by forging connections among them and increasing their interaction with regional and international human rights systems

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Conectas’ programme is divided into eight sub-areas; International Human Rights Colloquium, Global South Platform, Fellowship Programme, Sur Journal, Global South Human Rights Organisations at the UN, White Paper on Foreign Policy, Brazil in the UNHCR and other Multilateral Organs, and Brazil’s Delegation on the UPR Process of other countries. Conectas has been demonstrating positive results within all of the eight sub-areas.
The International Human Rights Colloquium gathered 128 human rights defenders (including non-traditional HR-defenders such as artists and journalists) from the global south with the theme of “the right to the streets”. This was the first time Conectas tried to reach a broader public by including individuals and groups who work to defend human rights but may not consider themselves as a traditional human rights defender or organisation. In particular participants from Russia, the Western Sahara, Tunisia and Turkey were represented at the colloquium. The colloquium works as a networking platform where participants are enabled to connect with each other and establish new relations in the area of human rights work.
Within the Global South Platform Conectas cooperates with human rights organisations in Latin America, Asia and Africa. Conectas takes part in various actions carried out locally, either from a distance or being present. The principal focus is on Latin America where Conectas has been involved in several activities during the programme period. An example of this is Conectas support to partner organisations in Mexico that are demanding investigation of the assassination of 43 Mexican students in September 2014, in relation to this case Conectas is also participating in endorsing pressure on the Mexican government to give clear answers. In Africa Conectas strengthened and fostered new ties with partner organisations, especially in Egypt, Zimbabwe, South Africa, the DRC, Guinea-Bissau and Kenya. In Asia Conectas is strengthening the partnership with in particular Chinese human rights defenders.
Conectas received three fellows through the fellowship programme in 2014. This time the fellows were senior human rights researchers and activists that came to Brazil and stayed with Conectas for a couple of months each. They were all authoring articles of the Sur Journal during their stay. In 2015 Conectas received two fellows who also participated in the Colloquium.
The Sur Journal is published in English online on a regular basis and has transformed to dialogue more with activists and practitioners than academics. The Sur Journal has been published for over ten years and human rights researchers and activists are contributing with articles. The 21st edition of the Sur Journal has the theme “War on drugs” and is strategically used to inform Ministers of Brazil’s Supreme Court who are currently judging a case that can result in decriminalisation of drug possession for personal consumption in Brazil.
Conectas has been active in training partner organisations on how to access and use international human rights mechanisms; the training was intended for organisations from the global south that work in the field of foreign policy and human rights. Conectas has exposed Brazil in the UNHCR in cases of human rights violations where in some cases this has led to further actions from the state or UN rapporteurs. Conectas participated in several hearings in the Inter-American Commission of Human Rights and has challenged Brazil’s dubious role in the system. In the UPR process Conectas together with partner organisations played an important part by preparing recommendations for hearings of nine different countries: North Korea, Ivory Coast, Equatorial Guinea, Ethiopia, Angola, Iran, the US, Croatia and Myanmar.
